title: Where does Firefox look for fonts?
content:
The font that I want Firefox to use for rendering web pages is in my system (/usr/share/fonts/truetype/), but Firefox doesn't include it in the list of fonts that I can choose from. Other applications (System Settings, LibreOffice) can use the font that I want.

Where does Firefox look for the fonts that it offers for me to choose from?

This issue was discussed in https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1354942, but the answer given was "The fonts are usually ordered in several section", which doesn't tell me where to put my font so that Firefox will see it.

I also think I remember seeing a comment somewhere that Firefox doesn't offer some of the fonts that it can see. How does it choose which fonts to offer? If I need to change my font so that Firefox will let me use it, I can do that with a font editor, but I need to know what the criteria are. Having glyphs for Basic Latin evidently isn't a requirement, see https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/avoid-problem-with-unsuitable-default-font/idi-p/37281.
creator: rparkins

title: Embedded Google Maps not working on Firefox
content:
Ever since I switched to Firefox I've noticed many websites with embedded Google Maps don't work properly on Firefox. It got really annoying but I ended up opening those websites on Chrome. I tried troubleshooting by clearing cache, disabling themes, and trying private mode but no dice. After some searching I came across a suggestion to disable WebGL (set webgl.disabled to true in about:config). That fixed the map issue but wondering if there's a solution that allows me to use these websites without disabling WebGL.

Attaching screenshots of the map issue with WebGL enabled and the fix with WebGL disabled.
creator: harsh2193

title: Tasto "Cerca nei segnalibri"
content: Salve, nella barra degli strumenti di Firefox, nel menu Segnalibri c'è un tasto "Cerca nei segnalibri", cliccando il quale vengono visualizzati i 10 segnalibri più recentemente salvati. Credo che questo sia controproducente nei riguardi della privacy (infatti già da tempo mantengo disattivati tutti i suggerimenti in base a segnalibri e cronologia). Chiedo pertanto se esiste il modo per non visualizzare più in "Cerca nei segnalibri" gli ultimi segnaibri salvati. Preciso per chiarezza: non voglio eliminare alcun segnalibro ma solo che non vengano visualizzati in "Cerca nei segnalibri". Grazie. Utilizzo Firefox 116.0.2 (64 bit) su Windows 10

title: Firefox ios app now having every single website blocked by screentime when previously didnt
content: I use firefox ios app on an iPhone 7. I also use screen time, which is an apple feature. After a recent update, screen time starting blocking every single website on firefox, as in would need the screen time passcode to unlock, when the screen time block all apps time comes around. Previously screentime would only block the app as a whole, so useful for not being on the phone as much but not completely frustrating if quickly needed to search something after the screen time lock all apps thing happens. Firefox is now being treated as how safari was when screentime was first introduced, as in as a browser rather than an app. Since previously firefox was only treated as an app by screentime. Which is how I'd prefer it to be treated for my settings. How do i get the app back to how it was behaving before the update?

title: Browsing after a period of inactivity
content:
After browsing the internet and leaving the browser open, my computer obviously goes to sleep. After i wake up the computer and try to use the browser the browser will refresh the page that was open before instead of opening the URL i type in. example. I browse for book titles on information technology management. I go to bed without closing the browser. The next morning I unlock the machine. The browser is in focus. I type www.google.com in the address bar. The page with the book titles from previous session refreshes and Google does not open. Only on typing the URL again will it open.,

I have searched for a solution but could not find it.

title: Urgent Request: Activation of :has() Property in Firefox for Critical CSS Functionality
content:
Hello there!

We are a team of web developers working on various major international projects. We have extensively utilized the :has() property in CSS across all our sites. However, we encountered an issue when someone tested it on Firefox, and the entire site broke. After thorough debugging, we discovered that the :has property does not function properly in Firefox. It was revealed that users need to manually adjust their browser settings for it to work, which is impractical for widespread use.

Unfortunately, we are unable to modify all our sites since the :has property forms the foundation of our CSS. My question is, when can we expect this feature to be enabled? We kindly request prompt activation of this feature. Given that it constitutes a significant CSS update, staying up to date with it is essential. Please find the attached photo for reference.

Thank you and best regards, Masood Ahmad
creator: masood.namal

title: Are my password on the local PC not protected?
content:
Hi, I've been using Firefox for decades and been saving passwords in it without any second thoughts, thinking they were fully secure.

Today I had to install a Yandex Browser for my work for the first time in my life (on a new clean Windows 10). It also asked to "make changes on my device", and I rejected it. What happened next absolutely terrified me. It immediately grabbed all the tabs, the sessions and, most importantly, the years worth of passwords from my Firefox. Does it mean that they just lie there unprotected, and any random piece of code even without the administrative privileges can just take them? I'm pretty sure I didn't click anything related to legitimate data sync.

title: audio stops video playback
content: Greetings, I've been having this issue for quite some time now and instead of just switching to another browser, I've come to the point where I've decided that it's time to fix this issue. It took me quite some time to figure out but now that I have, it's time to take it on. I frequently watch videos from various sites, both common and not so much but this happens across the spectrum. I usually have auto play off and volume muted because I'm in a super quiet building and one never knows how a video will start out unless we're familiar with the site, content, etc and have had some instances where a video would auto play and the volume would be cranked and I'm usually either Bluetoothed or wired to my home audio system so needless to say, I'm sure I've startled, surprised, or otherwise affected other tenants here, not to mention some embarrassing ones. Oh well. So now to my issue. For the past few months, possibly more, it could even be over a year now that I think about it, when I play a video, it's fine with the volume muted but when either I turn the volume on, or shut the mute off so that the videos will start with sound, they won't play. Some not at all and they won't even start, some will start for a split second and then stop, some will play for varying amounts of time, however usually not very long, and once in awhile one will play for a few minutes. I can't remember the last time a video played all the way through with the sound un-muted. It's been a while. This isn't an issue in any other browsers that I know of nor playing local content on installed media players. It's only firefox and it's any online streaming video from any site.
creator: r.dunne71
